text: there's a stretch of ocean off
California's coastline it's different
from the rest it starts around bodega
bay extends south to about 50 miles west
of San Francisco and ends in the Big Sur
region this area is infamous for shark
attacks
but not just any shark an estimated 38
percent of all great white shark attacks
in the u.s. happened here as a result
these waters bear the name red triangle
the red triangle includes roughly 200
miles of coastline but it's not the
beachgoers and surfers that attract
great whites to these waters it's the
rich population of other mammals like
sea lions harbor seals elephant seals
and sea otters great whites prefer to
prey on these animals instead of humans
however that doesn't stop the occasional
encounter contrary to popular belief
great whites don't mistake surfers for
other prey due to poor eyesight they
have great vision it actually comes down
to their inquisitive nature great whites
are notoriously curious and will taste
test unfamiliar objects including humans
in fact records indicate that great
whites have attacked more humans around
the world than any other shark but
before you swear off California's
beaches for the summer
remember that shark attacks are rare
each year less than 100 attacks occur
worldwide and only about five to fifteen
percent of those prove fatal
you have a greater chance of dying from
one of these animals instead luckily bug
spray is available at the local
drugstore
[Music]
